text.author: Pablo Ruiz Fabio, Clara Martínez Cantón, Thierry Poibeau
text.title: Distant Rhythm: Automatic Enjambment Detection on Four Centuries of Spanish Sonnets
text.summary1: (human) This paper presents a natural language processing system to identify and study enjambment in a large corpus of Spanish sonnets from the 15th to the 19th century.
text.summary2: (claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) This article presents an automated system that detects enjambment (the breaking of syntactic units across poetry lines) in Spanish sonnets, analyzing approximately 3,750 sonnets by 1,000 authors from the 15th to 19th century.
text.summary3: (gpt4o; postedited) The article introduces NLP software for detecting enjambment in Spanish sonnets, analyzing about 3750 sonnets by 1000 authors from the 15th-19th centuries, enabling large-scale studies of enjambment's syntactic triggers and stylistic effects, complementing previous studies and contributing to scholarly debates.
text.summary4: (Llama-3.2-3B-Instruct) Researchers developed a software tool to automatically detect enjambment in Spanish sonnets from the 15th to 19th centuries, covering a large corpus of 3750 sonnets and 1000 authors, and analyzed the results to better understand the stylistic effects of enjambment in Spanish poetry.
text.summary5: (Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) A study using natural language processing techniques has developed automated methods to detect enjambment in Spanish sonnets spanning four centuries, providing new insights into its usage patterns and supporting distant reading of poetic style over time.
